title: Private Insurance Guide for Autism Services
shortDescription: Understand how private health insurance covers autism services in Florida, including rights, requirements, and how to maximize benefits.
description: Private health insurance in Florida is required by law to provide coverage for autism spectrum disorder services for children under 18. This includes Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) therapy, speech therapy, occupational therapy, and diagnostic evaluations. Understanding your rights, how to navigate prior authorizations, and how to work effectively with your insurance company can help you access the care your child needs.

floridaLaw.title: Florida Autism Insurance Coverage Law
requirements: All fully-insured plans in Florida must cover autism services for children under 18
Minimum coverage of $36,000 per year for ABA therapy
Must cover speech therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy
Must cover diagnostic and assessment services
Cannot deny coverage based on age, as long as under 18
Cannot impose lifetime caps on autism coverage
exceptions: Self-funded employer plans are exempt from Florida law (governed by federal ERISA law)
Grandfathered health plans may have different requirements
Out-of-state insurance plans may not be subject to Florida mandates

typesOfPrivatePlans.description: Health insurance provided through your job. Most common type of private insurance. May be fully-insured (follows FL law) or self-funded (may not).
Individual plans purchased through Healthcare.gov. All marketplace plans in Florida must comply with autism coverage requirements.
Plans bought directly from insurance companies. Must comply with Florida autism coverage mandates.

keyTermsToKnow.prior_authorization: Approval from insurance required before starting therapy. Your provider typically handles this.
keyTermsToKnow.in_network: Providers contracted with your insurance. Using in-network providers results in lower costs.
keyTermsToKnow.out_of_network: Providers not contracted with your insurance. Usually requires higher copays and may not count toward deductible.
keyTermsToKnow.deductible: Amount you pay out-of-pocket before insurance starts covering costs.
keyTermsToKnow.copay: Fixed amount you pay per visit (e.g., $30 per therapy session).
keyTermsToKnow.coinsurance: Percentage you pay after meeting deductible (e.g., you pay 20%, insurance pays 80%).
keyTermsToKnow.out_of_pocket_maximum: Maximum amount you will pay in a year. After reaching this, insurance covers 100%.
keyTermsToKnow.medical_necessity: Insurance requirement that services must be necessary for treatment, not just helpful.

howToMaximizeBenefits: Always verify your plan's autism coverage before starting services
Keep copies of all prior authorization approvals
Request case management or care coordination if available
Track your annual ABA hours and dollar limits
Submit claims promptly and follow up on denials
Know your appeal rights if services are denied
Ask about Explanation of Benefits (EOB) to understand what was billed

commonChallenges.solution: Ask your provider to submit requests 2-4 weeks before starting therapy. Follow up with insurance if no response after 7 business days.
Request detailed denial reason. Work with your provider to submit clinical documentation. File an appeal with supporting evidence.
Track hours closely. Consider supplementing with school-based services, Florida waivers, or adjusting therapy intensity.
Ask if provider will accept your insurance rate. Request single-case agreement from insurance. Look for in-network alternatives.

yourRights: Right to request external review if internal appeals are denied
Right to reasonable accommodations under ADA
Right to timely prior authorization decisions (typically 3-15 days)
Right to clear explanation of coverage and denials
Protection from discrimination based on disability
